title: Five Hour Sunset
description: It's day one, so not a huge number of photos, most of the day was spend building this site while chasing the setting sun across the Atlantic en route to Rio (site improvements in the coming days). Photos can be found down below, I likely won't upload every day while other days I might pop some bonus text content under the photos. Those expecting beautiful prose turn back now.

title: Copacabana
description: Checked into the Pura Vida Hostel and found out a few fun things today: #1 Universal travel adaptors don't work in Brazil. #2 Chase debit cards don't work at ATM's in Brazil. #3 My sweat glands work really well in Brazil, it is humid af. For more revelations (and maybe that image of south america replaced with something else) tune in tomorrow.

title: The Botanical Gardens
description: The weather was a bit questionable today so I went for a big ol' stroll to: visit Ipanema beach, have lunch where The Girl from Ipanema was written (thanks for the recommendation Julio!) and see the botanical gardens. Turns out I'm a terrible wildlife photographer and missed all the monkeys and cool birds. Finished the day with happy hour and samba class back at the Pura Vida.

title: Caipirinhas & Beach Volleyball
description: It's been 30¬∞ and sunny for the last 2 days so I've barely left the beach and rarely brought my phone with me so not many good photos, sorry! I'm starting to think that portion control isn't a common phrase in Brazil as every meal is absolutely behemoth. Also I found a table in the shape of a butt, perfect for bottomless drinks hour.

title: Thunderstorms & Rugby
description: The thunderstorms in Rio are intense! I thought a bomb had gone off near my hostel last night. With weather like this the only thing to do was find an Irish pub (they really are everywhere) and watch the rugby. Also destroyed the competition at karaoke, although there is no photo or video proof so you'll just have to trust me. 10 points to anyone who can guess the flag.

title: Morro Dois Irm√£os
description: A group of us went for a morning hike up the two brothers, which stand over the west side of Rio and give you an unreal view of the city and the largets favela in Latin America. A motorbike ride through the favela gets you to the start of the hike (sorry mum) and after an hour or two of sweaty jungle climbing you get a pretty sweet reward for your efforts.

title: Couple Days of Culture
description: Visited the museum of tomorrow and saw the sites up in the centre of town with a couple of friends. Ooh hostel friends. Also tried to go visit Christ the Redeemer but they closed it down for the day due to a storm toppling some trees, so going back to do that in a couple of days, hopefully with better weather.

title: Ipanema
description: Spent the last few days at the Mango Tree in Ipanema. Great place for parties & meeting people, would definitely recommend. I also went up to see the Christ the Redeemer statue, which actually looked really cool looming out of the clouds, shame about the non-existent view from the top but I did get to see some monkeys. Time now for a hungover 4 hour bus ride

title: Paraty
description: The next stop on the journey is Paraty, a colourful little colonial town about 4 hours from Rio. Shoutout to Sarah for the recommendation, it's a really beautiful place, the weather is great, the hostel has a pool and the beer is cold so life is good.

title: Jungle Treehouse
description: So this stop was purely based on a recommendation from KK, she big shoutout to her because the Remo Hostel is pretty sweet, it's situated on a mountainside in the middle of the jungle with amazing views out towards the ocean. It was beautiful when I arrived but has rained consistently since, the clue was in the name rainforest I suppose. Anyway seeing as nobody else speaks any English this should be a good time to learn some Portguese.

title: Ilha Grande
description: Arrived on the Big Island, it's one of those places that I knew I was going to enjoy as soon as I arrived. Really laid back place with loads of places to eat, drink and meet people as well as some amazing scenery. I checked into my awesome, if somewhat confusing, chapel room (see below) at the Mambembe hostel, met a couple of girls and went out for drinks, turns out one of them grew up in West Byfleet, small world, huh. Continued below...
additionalContent:
Despite a decent hangover from a heavy night on the caipirinhas I thought a little hike would be a good shout for day 2. What I didn't expect was for the hike to be a 5 hour slog through the jungle and for it to be 31¬∞, I also took the smart decision to take a ‚Äúshortcut‚Äù based on a comment left on a message board, which took me off the path and down a steep narrow gulley I affectionately named Spider Alley, only for the path to become a river thanks to all the rain over the past few days. That of course meant I had to hike back up The Alley, so lesson learned there. 
 To be honest it was worth it in the end for the views, the waterfalls and the completely deserted beach surrounded by two rivers as they reached the sea. So if you're ever on Ilha Grande I'd recommend the Dois Rios hike, but maybe wear something other than white trainers unless you want them painted brown. After hiking the 12km back to Abr√£ao, I rewarded myself with a massive steak on the beach at a restaurant as inventively named as the island itself: Steak & Beach.

title: Ciao Brazil
description: I spent my last few days on Ilha Grande laying on the beach and paddle boarding during a rare spell of good weather, alongside some caiparinha & beer fueled late night hostel debates on hot topic issues. Pretty sure I know less about Gaza than before we started. Back in Rio today enjoying the last of the sun before I fly to Argentina tomorrow.

title: Hola Argentina
description: Buenos Aires is cold and wet üòÖ. It's about 15 degrees colder here than it was when I took off from Rio, good job I only packed a single fleece for this trip! Oh well the restaurants are warm and the steak dinner and bottle of wine I had last night cost all of ¬£12. It's mainly just been flights and hotels for the last couple days so no good photos. But there's plenty of the sun in the forecast for this week so that should change soon, I'm staying in Recoleta for the next few days so if anyone has recommendations let me know.

title: Recoleta
description: I love Buenos Aires. It's got a very relaxed vibe and feels very European when you're seated at a little cafe in the sunshine having lunch. I did the customary tour of the Recoleta Cemetery while the weather was overcast on the first day. It's a really interesting mix of styles & architecture; it doesn't really feel like a graveyard at all. Since then, the sun has come out, so time has been spent exploring, eating empanadas, drinking beer, and sitting in the street watching Boca Juniors narrowly losing the Copa Libertadores final with what felt like every single other inhabitant of BA.

title: Palermo
description: My last couple of days in Buneos Aires were spent mainly in Palermo, enjoying the parks in the sunshine as well as the great food and wine in the center, I would definitely come back to BA. A group of us went to something called the Argentina Experience, where you try some of BA's favorite dishes, as well as doing a cocktail, empanada, and mat√© course. I ended up winning the creative empanada folding contest with a 4-leaf clover (definitely intended it to be that shape from the beginning, not just a way to get four fillings into one empanada). I'm writing this from the airport, waiting for my flight up to Puerto Iguazu, where it's 30+¬∞, to go see the falls.

title: Iguazu Falls
description: Had a great couple of days in Iguazu. It was blisteringly hot so standing in the spray from the largest waterfall system in the world was a pretty great place to be, pretty spectacular too, I can defnitely see why it's one of the one of the world's new seven natural wonders. Also saw a load of cool wildlife I'd never seen before, in fact I'd never even heard of a coati or a nasua, I managed to snap a photo of a few of them but the capuchins were too quick for me. Thankfully we got off the ground early this morning before the thunderstorms began, so I'm back in BA now for a connecting flight to Mendoza.

title: Mendoza
description: Sorry for the wait on an update but Mendoza was pretty action packed and I never really found the time to do this. It was definitely my favourite place that I've visited so far, so shoutout to all of you who recommended it. The Gorilla Hostel in Mendoza is amazing and I met so many great people there who made the horseback riding, cycle wine tours and hungover days in the pool so much fun. In fact it was really hard to leave for Bariloche, especially knowing that it was 30¬∞ in Mendoza and 3¬∞ in Bariloche, but a small crew of us from the Gorilla are now safely checked in to Penthouse 1004 in Bariloche so watch out for photos from there in a few days time.

title: Bariloche
description: Four days in Bariloche flew by. The town is essentially a Swiss mountain village that has been dropped onto the Northern tip of Patagonia complete with chocolate shops, fondue restaurants and ski lifts. The weather here is pretty unpredictable and so is the scenery. The area around town seems to have parts of Nevada, Utah, California, Northern Scotland, New Zeland and of course Switzerland all stitched together. Continued below...
additionalContent: Yesterday 4 of us rented a car for the equiliviant of ¬£6 each (with petrol) and did a 12 hour round trip through the seven lakes to San Martin which was an amazing drive with it's own rally special stage to get to some of the lakes. Once we got to San Martin the clouds parted for a while so we had time to do a little hike on the cliffs surrounding the town/lake and then we found a lovely little restaurant for some fresh smoked lake trout sorrentinos. I'm currently writing this on a 6 hour bus through the Andes to Puerto Montt in Chile so I can fly further south into the heart of Patagonia to hike some pointy mountains (and yes it's the most beautiful bus ride I've ever taken).
